revision.text:
As defined by [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]], '''geo-literacy''' is "the ability to use [[geographic]] understanding and geographic reasoning to make decisions".<ref name="nationalgeographic1">{{cite web |url=http://education.nationalgeographic.com/education/geoliteracy/?ar_a=1&force_AR=True |title=Geo-Literacy |accessdate=June 26, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416071705/http://education.nationalgeographic.com/education/geoliteracy/?ar_a=1&force_AR=True |archivedate=April 16, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
==History== The term "geo-literacy" arose from the National Geographic Society's "Fight against Geographic Illiteracy." The organization released various media to help explain the concept to the general public. In an editorial, Daniel C. Edelson, vice president for education at National Geographic, said, "The National Geographic Society's concern for geo-literacy comes from our mission. We see geo-literacy as providing the tools that will enable communities to protect [[natural resource|natural]] and cultural resources, reduce violent [[Armed conflict|conflict]], and improve the [[quality of life]] worldwide. However, having a geo-literate populace is also critical for maintaining [[Competition (economics)|economic competitiveness]], quality of life, and national security in our modern, interconnected world.",<ref>{{cite web | url=http://geography.about.com/b/2012/05/13/geo-literacy.htm | title=Geo-Literacy | publisher=About.com | date=May 13, 2012 | accessdate=June 26, 2012 | author=Rosenberg, Matt}}</ref> and have released various media to help explain it to the general public.<ref name="nationalgeographic1"/> In addition, the National Geographic Society set up the Fund for Geo-literacy, in which donations help fund the printing of materials for education, professional development for the educators, and programs to help build awareness of the importance of geo-literacy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://education.nationalgeographic.com/education/program/fund-for-geo-literacy/?ar_a=1&force_AR=True |title=Fund for Geo-Literacy |accessdate=June 26, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120625130105/http://education.nationalgeographic.com/education/program/fund-for-geo-literacy/?ar_a=1 |archivedate=June 25, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
==Components== According to Edelson, the 3 components of geo-literacy are:<ref name="nationalgeographic1"/> * Interactions-Understanding of human and natural systems * Interconnections-Geographic reasoning * Implications-Systematic decision-making
==Educational activities== "Kid World Citizen", a site which provides "multicultural, educational activities to teach...kids about the world", and who, listed the following "age-appropriate lessons to increase geo-literacy in primary school students":<ref>{{cite web | url=http://kidworldcitizen.org/2012/05/13/what-is-geo-literacy/ | title=What is Geo-Literacy? | publisher=Kid World Citizen | date=May 13, 2012 | accessdate=June 26, 2012}}</ref>
* Explore different homes around the world and guess why the types of home fit their environment * Discover why certain cultures celebrate certain holidays, and what is important to them * Investigate different [[habitats]] and [[biomes]], such as the [[rainforest]]; look at tangible ways kids can prevent their destruction * Surround kids with geography: study maps, [[cartography|create maps]], follow maps, play with maps. The more you develop their spatial intelligence when they’re younger, the more kids will understand their place in this world. * Learn about the [[water cycle]] and the conserving and managing our freshwater resources * Research your child’s favorite animal, turning it into a global lesson about protecting their habitat and food sources; what decisions can we make that will affect the outcome of this animal?
==Research Studies and Education Projects== In 2012, InTeGrate ("a community effort to improve geoscience literacy and build a workforce that can make use of geoscience to solve societal issues") held a Module Author Meeting from May 16–18 on the topic.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://serc.carleton.edu/integrate/info_team_members/meetings/geo_lit_agenda.html | title=Module Author Meeting Agenda | accessdate=June 26, 2012}}</ref>
==Earlier Uses of the Term "geo-literacy"==
In 2002, Robert E. Nolan of the [[Education Resources Information Center]] published a research report/journal article entitled "Geo-Literacy: How Well Adults Understand the World in Which They Live", which included "a test of physical and geopolitical geography...completed by 321 adults". The years of formal education and age were correlated with geographic literacy, and informal learning, such as travel, reading, media, was used as the primary source of geographic knowledge for those with higher educational attainment. A notable finding was that women, regardless of education level, scored significantly lower than men."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/search/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=EJ658647&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=no&accno=EJ658647 | title=Geo-Literacy: How Well Adults Understand the World in Which They Live | accessdate=June 26, 2012}}</ref>
In 2001, the [[Arizona Geographic Information Council|Arizona Geographic Alliance]] launched a project called "The GeoLiteracy Project" that integrated geography education into reading and writing instruction. In this case, their term "GeoLiteracy" referred to the integration of geography and traditional language arts literacy.
In 1997, Linda Ferguson and Eva LaMar established an educational project they called "The Geo-Literacy Project". LaMar describes geo-literacy as "the use of visual learning and communication tools to build an in-depth understanding -- or literacy -- of geography, [[geology]], and local [[history]]." <ref>{{cite web|last=Ball|first=Ashley|title=Geo-Literacy: Using Technology to Forge New Ground|url=http://www.edutopia.org/geo-literacy-forging-new-ground|work=Edutopia|accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref>
==External links== * [http://vimeo.com/album/1922395 National Geographic videos: "What is Geo-Literacy?" and "Why is Geo-Literacy Important?"] * [http://www.directionsmag.com/articles/the-geo-literacy-coalition-tackles-americans-geographic-preparation/197867 Directions Magazine article "The Geo-Literacy Coalition Tackles Americans’ Geographic Preparation"]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Geography topics}}
[[Category:Geography]]

revision.text:
'''Ideal observer analysis''' is a method for investigating how information is processed in a [[perceptual system]].<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Tanner Jr, Wilson P. |author2=Birdsall, T. G. |year=1958 |title=Definitions of d′ and η as Psychophysical Measures |journal=[[Journal of the Acoustical Society of America]] |volume=30 |issue=10 |pages=922–928 |doi=10.1121/1.1909408 |pmid= |pmc= |url=http://asadl.org/jasa/resource/1/jasman/v30/i10/p922_s1?isAuthorized=no |accessdate=August 19, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Visual search techniques: proceedings of a symposium, held in the Smithsonian Auditorium, Washington, D. C., April 7 and 8, 1959 |chapter=The ideal sensor system as approached through statistical decision theory and the theory of signal detectability |last=Tanner Jr |first=W. P. |authorlink= |last2=Jones |first2=R. Clark |year=1960 |publisher=[[United States National Academies]] |location= |isbn= |pages=59–68 |accessdate=August 19, 2012 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=rV8rAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA59&lpg=PA59&dq=The+ideal+sensor+system+is+approached+through+statistical+decision+theory+and+the+theory+of+signal+detectability#v=onepage&q=The%20ideal%20sensor%20system%20is%20approached%20through%20statistical%20decision%20theory%20and%20the%20theory%20of%20signal%20detectability&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=W. P. Tanner Jr. |year=1961 |title=Physiological implications of psychophysical data |journal=[[Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences]] |volume=89 |issue= 5|pages=752–65 |doi= 10.1111/j.1749-6632.1961.tb20176.x|pmc= |pmid=13775211 }}</ref> It is also a basic principle that guides modern research in [[perception]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Perception as Bayesian Inference |last=Knill |first=David C. |last2=Whitman |first2=Richards |authorlink2=Whitman Richards |year=1996 |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |location= |isbn= 9780521461092|page= |pages= |accessdate=August 19, 2012 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=tcx-XfmXegUC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Perception+as+Bayesian+Inference#v=onepage&q=Perception%20as%20Bayesian%20Inference&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Vision: Coding and Efficiency |chapter=The quantum efficiency of vision |last=Pelli |first=D. G. |editor1-first=Colin |editor1-last=Blakemore |year=1993 |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |location= |isbn= 9780521447690|pages=3–24 |accessdate=August 19, 2012 |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/?id=xGJ_DxN3eygC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Vision:+Coding+and+Efficiency#v=onepage&q=Vision%3A%20Coding%20and%20Efficiency&f=false}}</ref>
The ''ideal observer'' is a theoretical system that performs a specific task in an optimal way. If there is uncertainty in the task, then perfect performance is impossible and the ideal observer will make errors.
''Ideal performance'' is the theoretical upper limit of performance. It is theoretically impossible for a real system to perform better than ideal. Typically, real systems are only capable of sub-ideal performance.
This technique is useful for analyzing psychophysical data (see [[psychophysics]]).
==Definition==
Many definitions of this term have been offered.
'''Geisler (2003)'''<ref>{{cite book |title=The Visual Neurosciences |chapter=Ideal Observer Analysis |last=Geisler |first=Wilson S. |editor1-first=Leo M. |editor1-last=Chalupa |editor2-first=John S. |editor2-last=Werner |year=2003 |publisher=[[MIT Press]] |location= |isbn= 9780262033084|pages=825–837 |accessdate=August 19, 2012 |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/?id=AN-sdYjcyvAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Visual+Neurosciences#v=onepage&q=Ideal%20Observer%20analysis&f=false}}</ref> (slightly reworded): The central concept in ideal observer analysis is the ''ideal observer'', a theoretical device that performs a given task in an optimal fashion given the available information and some specified constraints. This is not to say that ideal observers perform without error, but rather that they perform at the physical limit of what is possible in the situation. The fundamental role of uncertainty and noise implies that ideal observers must be defined in probabilistic (statistical) terms. ''Ideal observer analysis'' involves determining the performance of the ideal observer in a given task and then comparing its performance to that of a real [[perceptual system]], which (depending on the application) might be the system as a whole, a subsystem, or an elementary component of the system (e.g. a neuron).
==Sequential ideal observer analysis==
In '''sequential ideal observer analysis''',<ref>{{cite journal |author=W. S. Geisler |year=1989 |title=Sequential ideal-observer analysis of visual discriminations |journal=[[Psychological Review]] |volume=96 |issue=2 |pages=267–314 |doi= 10.1037/0033-295x.96.2.267|pmc= |pmid=2652171 }}</ref> the goal is to measure a real system's performance deficit (relative to ideal) at different processing stages. Such an approach is useful when studying systems that process information in discrete (or semi-discrete) stages or modules.
==Natural and pseudo-natural tasks==
To facilitate experimental design in the laboratory, an artificial task may be designed so that the system's performance in the task may be studied. If the task is too artificial, the system may be pushed away from a natural mode of operation. Depending on the goals of the experiment, this may diminish its [[external validity]].
In such cases, it may be important to keep the system operating naturally (or almost naturally) by designing a pseudo-natural task. Such tasks are still artificial, but they attempt to mimic the natural demands placed on a system. For example, the task might employ stimuli that resemble natural [[scene (perception)|scenes]] and might test the system's ability to make potentially useful judgments about these stimuli.
[[Scene statistics|Natural scene statistics]] are the basis for calculating ideal performance in natural and pseudo-natural tasks. This calculation tends to incorporate elements of [[Detection theory|signal detection theory]], [[information theory]], or [[estimation theory]].
==Notes==
<references/>
[[Category:Perception]] [[Category:Neuroscience]]

revision.text:
{{Use Indian English|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox University |name = Indian Statistical Institute |image = [[File:Indianstatisticalinstitutelogo.svg|200px|ISI Logo]] |caption = Logo of the Indian Statistical Institute |motto = ''भिन्नेष्वैक्यस्य दर्शनम्'' |founders = [[Prasanta Chandra Mahalanobis]] |established = {{Start date|17 December 1931}} |type = [[Public university]] |staff = 1000 |faculty = 255 |head_label = Director |head = [[Sanghamitra Bandyopadhyay]] |students = 375 |undergrad = 110 |postgrad = 225 |doctoral = 40 |city = [[Kolkata]] (headquarters), [[Delhi]], [[Chennai]], [[Bangalore]], [[Tezpur]], [[Giridih]], [[Hyderabad]] |state = |country = [[India]] |campus = Urban |nickname = ISI |affiliations = [[Association of Indian Universities|AIU]] |website = [http://www.isical.ac.in isical.ac.in] }}
[[File:ISI Delhi map.svg|thumb|Map of the Delhi campus]] '''Indian Statistical Institute''' ('''ISI''') is an academic [[Institute of National Importance|institute of national importance]] as recognised by a 1959 act of the Indian parliament.<ref name=unsd>{{cite web |url = http://unstats.un.org/unsd/dnss/docViewer.aspx?docID=417 |title = UNSD Document – The Indian Statistical Institute Act 1959 |publisher = United Nations Statistics Division |accessdate = 14 November 2012 }}</ref> It grew out of the Statistical Laboratory set up by [[Prasanta Chandra Mahalanobis]] in [[Presidency College, Kolkata]]. Established in 1931, this [[public university]] of India is one of the oldest and most prestigious institutions focused on statistics, and its early reputation led it to being adopted as a model for the first US institute of Statistics set up at the [[Research Triangle]], [[North Carolina]] by [[Gertrude Mary Cox]].<ref name=cox>{{cite journal | title=Mahalanobis and the Art and Science of Statistics: The Early Days | author=Ghosh, JK | journal=[[Indian Journal of History of Science]] | volume=29 | issue=1 | page=90 | year=1994}} </ref>
Mahalanobis, the founder of ISI, was deeply influenced by wisdom and guidance of [[Rabindranath Tagore]] and [[Brajendranath Seal]]. Under his leadership, the institute initiated and promoted the interaction of Statistics with natural and social sciences to advance the role of Statistics as a key technology by explicating the twin aspects{{spaced ndash}}its general applicability and its dependence on other disciplines for its own development. The institute is now considered as one of the foremost centres in the world for training and research in Computer science, Statistics, Quantitative Economics and related sciences.
ISI has its headquarters in [[Baranagar]], [[Kolkata, West Bengal]]. It has four subsidiary centres focused in academics at [[Delhi]], [[Bangalore]], [[Chennai]] and [[Tezpur]], and a branch at [[Giridih]]. In addition, the Institute has a network of units of [[Statistical Process Control|Statistical Quality Control]] and [[Operations Research]] at [[Vadodara]], [[Coimbatore]], [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]], [[Mumbai]] and [[Pune]] engaged in guiding the industries, within and outside India, in developing the most up–to–date quality management systems and solving critical problems of quality, reliability and productivity.
Primary activities of ISI are research and training of Statistics, development of theoretical Statistics and its applications in various natural and social sciences. Originally affiliated with the [[University of Calcutta]], the institute was declared an institute of national importance in 1959, through an act of Indian parliament, Indian Statistical Institute act, 1959. ISI functions under the [[Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (India)|Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation]] (MOSPI) of the [[Government of India]].<ref name=mospi>{{cite web |url = http://mospi.nic.in/Mospi_New/site/inner.aspx?status=2&menu_id=5 |title = About Ministry |publisher = [[Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (India)|Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation]] of the [[Government of India]] |accessdate = 19 November 2012 }}</ref>
Key areas of expertise of ISI are [[Computer science]], Statistics, [[Mathematics]], [[Mathematical economics]], [[Operations Research]] and [[Information Science]] and it is one of the few research oriented Indian schools offering courses at both the undergraduate and graduate level.
== History == ISI's origin can be traced back to the Statistical Laboratory in [[Presidency College, Kolkata]] set up by Mahalanobis, who worked in the Physics Department of the college in the 1920s. During 1913–15, he did his [[Tripos]] in Mathematics and Physics at [[University of Cambridge]],<ref name=hist1013>{{harvnb|Ghosh|Maiti|Bera|2010|p=1013}}</ref> where he came across ''[[Biometrika]]'', a journal of Statistics founded by [[Karl Pearson]].<ref name=hist1019>{{harvnb|Ghosh|Maiti|Bera|2010|p=1019}}</ref> Since 1915, he taught Physics at Presidency College,<ref name=hist1013/> but his interest in Statistics grew under the guidance of [[polymath]] [[Brajendranath Seal]].<ref name=hist1019/> Many colleagues of Mahalanobis took an interest in Statistics and the group grew in the Statistical Laboratory. Considering the extensive application of Statistics in solving various problems in real life such as analyzing multivariate anthropometric data, applying sample surveys as a method of data collection, analyzing meteorological data, estimating crop yield etc., this group, particularly, Mahalanobis and his younger colleagues [[Subhendu Sekhar Bose|S. S. Bose]] and [[Harish Chandra Sinha|H. C. Sinha]] felt the necessity of forming a specialized institute to facilitate research and learning of Statistics.<ref name=evoln22>{{harvnb|Ghosh|Maiti|Rao|Sinha|1999|p=22}}</ref>
On 17 December 1931, Mahalonobis held a meeting with Pramatha Nath Banerji (Minto Professor of Economics), Nikhil Ranjan Sen (Khaira Professor of Applied Mathematics) and Sir [[R. N. Mukherji]].<ref name=evoln22/><ref name=obit>{{cite book | first = C. R | last = Rao | authorlink = Calyampudi Radhakrishna Rao | year = 1973 | title = Prasantha Chandra Mahalanobis. 1893–1972 | publisher = ''Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society''| volume = 19 | pages=454–492}}</ref><ref name=bio>{{cite book | last = Rudra | first = A | year = 1996 | title = ''Prasanta Chandra Mahalanobis: A Biography'' | publisher = Oxford University Press}}</ref> This meeting led to the establishment of the Indian Statistical Institute (ISI), which was formally registered on 28 April 1932, as a non-profit distributing learned society under the Societies Registration Act XXI of 1860.<ref name=obit/><ref name=bio/> Later, the institute was registered under the West Bengal Societies Registration Act XXVI of 1961 amended in 1964.<ref name=hist>{{cite web|url=http://www.isical.ac.in/history.php|title=History of ISI|publisher=Indian Statistical Institute|accessdate=22 November 2012}}</ref> Mukherjee accepted the role of the president of ISI and held this position until his death in 1936.<ref name=hist/> In 1953,<ref name=hist1020>{{harvnb|Ghosh|Maiti|Bera|2010|p=1020}}</ref> ISI was relocated to a property owned by Professor Mahalanobis, named "Amrapali", in [[Baranagar]], which is now a municipality at the northern outskirts of Kolkata.
In 1931, Mahalanobis was the only person working at ISI, and he managed it with an annual expenditure of Rs.250. It gradually grew with the pioneering work of a group of his colleagues including S. S. Bose, [[Samarendra Kumar Mitra]] (Head of the Computing Machines and Electronics Laboratory and designer of India's first computer), [[J. M. Sengupta]], [[Raj Chandra Bose]], [[Samarendra Nath Roy]], [[K. R. Nair]], [[R. R. Bahadur]], [[Gopinath Kallianpur]], [[D. B. Lahiri]], and [[Anil Kumar Gain]]. [[Pitamber Pant]], who had received training in Statistics at the institute, went on to become a secretary to the first Prime Minister of India, [[Jawaharlal Nehru]], and was a great source of help and support to the institute.<ref name=obit/>
The institute started a training section in 1938. In due course, many of the early workers left the ISI for careers in the USA or for positions in public/private sector in India. By the 1940s, the ISI was internationally known and was taken as a model when the first institute of Statistics was set up in the United States by Gertrude Cox{{spaced ndash}}perhaps the only time an institute in a developing country was used as a model in a developed country.<ref name=cox/>
As asked by the Government of India, in 1950, ISI designed and planned a comprehensive socio–economic national sample survey covering rural India. The organisation named National Sample Survey (NSS) was founded in 1950 for conducting this survey.<ref name=evoln1718>{{harvnb|Ghosh|Maiti|Rao|Sinha|1999|pp=17–18}}</ref> The field work was performed by the Directorate of NSS, functioning under the [[Ministry of Finance (India)|Ministry of Finance]], whereas the other tasks such as planning of the survey, training of field workers, review, data processing and tabulation were executed by ISI.<ref name=evoln1718/> In 1961, the Directorate of NSS started functioning under the [[Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (India)#Department of Statistics|Department of Statistics]] of Government of India, and later in 1971, the design and analysis wing of NSS was shifted from ISI to the Department of Statistics forming the [[National Sample Survey Organisation]] (NSSO).<ref name=evoln1718/>
[[J. B. S. Haldane]] joined the ISI as a research professor from August 1957, and stayed on until February 1961, when he had a falling out with ISI Director P.C. Mahalanobis over Haldane's going on a much-publicized hunger strike to protest the United States pressuring U.S. National Science Fair winners [[Gary Botting]] and Susan Brown from attending an ISI banquet to which many prominent Indian scientists had been invited.<ref>"Haldane on Fast: Insult by USIS Alleged," ''Times of India'', 19 January 1961; "Protest Fast by Haldane: USIS’s Anti-Indian Activities," ''Times of India'', 18 January 1961; "Situation was Misunderstood, Scholars Explain," ''Times of India'', 20 January 1961; "USIS Explanation does not satisfy Haldane: Protest fast continues," ''Times of India'', 18 January 1960; "USIS Claim Rejected by Haldane: Protest Fast to Continue," ''Times of India'', 18 January 1961; "Haldane Not Satisfied with USIS Apology: Fast to Continue," Free Press Journal, 18 January 1961; "Haldane Goes on Fast In Protest Against U.S. Attitude," ''Times of India'', 18 January 1961; "Haldane to continue fast: USIS explanation unsatisfactory," ''Times of India'', 19 January 1961; "Local boy in hunger strike row," ''Toronto Star'', 20 January 1961; "Haldane, Still on Fast, Loses Weight: U.S.I.S. Act Termed 'Discourteous'," ''Indian Express'', 20 January 1961; "Haldane Slightly Tired on Third Day of Fast," ''Times of India'', 21 January 1961; "Haldane Fasts for Fourth Consecutive Day," ''Globe and Mail'', 22 January 1961</ref> Haldane helped the ISI grow in biometrics.<ref>{{cite journal|title=On Some Aspects of the Life and Work of John Burdon Sanderson Haldane, F.R.S., in India|first=Krishna R.|last=Dronamraju|journal=Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London|volume=41| issue=2|year=1987|pages=211–237 |doi=10.1098/rsnr.1987.0006 |pmid=11622022}}</ref> Haldane also played a key role in developing the structure and content of the courses offered by ISI.
Until 1959, ISI was associated with the [[University of Calcutta]]. By 'The Indian Statistical Institute Act 1959' of the Parliament of India, amended in 1995, ISI was declared an institute of national importance,<ref name=unsd/> and was authorised to hold examinations and to grant degrees and diplomas in Statistics, Mathematics, Computer Science, Quantitative Economics, and in any other subject related to Statistics as identified by the Institute from time to time.<ref name=unsd/> ISI is a [[public university]], as the same act also states that ISI would be funded by the Central Government of India.<ref name=unsd/>
ISI had by the 1960s started establishing special service units in New Delhi, Chennai, Bangalore, Mumbai and Hyderabad to provide consultancy services to business, industry and governmental public service organisations in the areas of Statistical Process Control, Operations Research and Industrial Engineering. Additionally, Bangalore had a [[Documentation Research and Training Centre]] (DRTC). In the early 1970s, the Delhi and Bangalore units were converted to teaching centres. In 2008, ISI Chennai was upgraded to a teaching centre.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.hindu.com/2008/07/27/stories/2008072758580800.htm |title = Pranab Mukherjee inaugurates Chennai centre of Indian Statistical Institute |publisher = The Hindu |date = 27 July 2008 |accessdate = 2008-10-01 }}</ref> In 2011, ISI added a new centre in [[Tezpur]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-07-24/guwahati/29809485_1_indian-statistical-institute-pranab-mukherjee-union-minister |title = New life for Look East policy with Tezpur ISI |publisher = The Times of India, Guwahati Edition |date = 24 July 2011 |accessdate = 2012-11-13 }}</ref>
== Administration == ISI functions as an autonomous institute under the Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (MOSPI), which is the nodal ministry of the Government of India that ensures the functioning of ISI in accordance with The Indian Statistical Institute Act 1959.<ref name=mospi/> ISI Council is the highest policy–making body of the institute.<ref name=isicouncil>{{cite web | url = http://www.isical.ac.in/officebearers.php | title = Office Bearers | publisher = Indian Statistical Institute | accessdate = 15 December 2012}}</ref> Members of this council include the President of ISI, the Chairman of ISI, representatives of the Government of India including one representative of [[Reserve Bank of India|RBI]], scientists not employed in ISI including one representative from the [[Planning Commission (India)|Planning Commission of India]] and one representative of the [[University Grants Commission (India)|UGC]], representatives of scientific and non-scientific workers of ISI, and representative from academic staff of ISI, including the Director of ISI and the Dean of Studies of ISI.<ref name=isicouncil/> [[Bimal Kumar Roy]] was the Director until 10 June 2015; in a move unique in the history of the Institute, he was removed from his post via a notice posted on the web site of the Ministry of Statistics and Planning.<ref name=mospi-10-06-2015>{{cite web | url = http://mospi.nic.in/mospi_new/upload/appoint_Dir_isi_10june15.pdf | title = Termination Letter | publisher = Ministry of Statistics and Planning | accessdate = 10 June 2015 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150614135525/http://mospi.nic.in/mospi_new/upload/appoint_Dir_isi_10june15.pdf | archivedate = 14 June 2015 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>

== Objectives == The major objectives of the ISI are<ref name=obj>{{cite web|url=http://www.isical.ac.in/objectives.php|title=Welcome to Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata|website=www.isical.ac.in}}</ref> to facilitate research and training of Statistics, to indulge in development of statistical theory and in application of statistical techniques{{spaced ndash}}in the scenarios of planning at national level and in theoretical development of natural and social sciences, to participate in the process of data collection and analysis, to operate related projects in planning and improvement of efficiency of management and production.
The Sanskrit phrase भिन्नेष्वैक्यस्य दर्शणम् (Bhinneswaykyasya Darshanam), which literally means the philosophy of unity in diversity, is incorporated in the logo of the institute, and is the motto of ISI.<ref name=obj/>
== Academics == [[File:Isical02.jpg|thumb|New Academic Building, ISI Kolkata]] [[File:ISI Delhi main building - front (day).JPG|thumb|Main office building, ISI Delhi]] [[File:ISI Bangalore main building.JPG|thumb|Main building, ISI Bangalore]] Traditionally, ISI offers fewer programs (and admits fewer students) than most other degree granting academic institutions. Following the empowerment for granting degrees in the subject of Statistics as per the ISI Act 1959, in 1960, ISI initiated bachelor level degree program Bachelor of Statistics and master level degree course Master of Statistics, and also began awarding research level degrees such as PhD and DSc.<ref name=sbrao/> Later, ISI started offering Master of Technology (MTech) courses in Computer Science and in Quality, Reliability & Operations Research (QR&OR); these courses got recognition from [[All India Council for Technical Education]] (AICTE).<ref name=sbrao/> As ISI Act of 1959 was amended by the Parliament of India in 1995, ISI was empowered to confer degrees and diplomas in subjects such as Mathematics, Quantitative Economics, Computer Science, and other subjects related to Statistics and Operations Research as determined by ISI from time to time.<ref name=sbrao/> Apart from the degree courses, ISI offers few diploma and certificate courses, special diploma courses for international students via ISEC, and special courses in collaboration with [[Central Statistical Organisation|CSO]] for training probationary officers of [[Indian Statistical Service]] (ISS).<ref name=isiprospectus>{{cite web | url = http://www.isical.ac.in/~deanweb/GENPRSP2K12.pdf | format = PDF | title = Prospectus, 2012–13 | publisher = Indian Statistical Institute | accessdate = 1 December 2012}}</ref>
=== Degree courses === ISI offers two undergraduate programs, viz. Bachelor of Statistics (Honours) (B.Stat) and Bachelor of Mathematics (Honours) (B. Math),<ref name=prog>{{cite web |url = http://www.isical.ac.in/academicprogramme.php |title = Academic Programme |publisher = Indian Statistical Institute |accessdate = 2012-11-13}}</ref> seven graduate programs, viz. Master of Statistics (M. Stat), Master of Mathematics (M. Math), Master of Science in Quantitative Economics (MSQE), Master of Science in Library and Information Science (MSLIS), Master of Science in Quality Management Science (MSQMS), Master of Technology in Computer Science (MTech–CS) and Master of Technology in Quality, Reliability and Operations Research (MTech–QROR),<ref name=prog/> three PG Diploma programs, viz Post Graduate Diploma in Computer Applications (PGDCA)<ref name=pgdca>{{cite web |url = http://www.isical.ac.in/~placement/assets/docs/PGDCASyllabus.pdf |title = PGDCA Programme |publisher = Indian Statistical Institute |accessdate = 2016-06-26}}</ref> and P.G. Diploma in Statistical Methods and Analytics and research fellowships towards obtaining a PhD degree.<ref name=prog/> The third PG diploma program being in collaboration with [[IIM Calcutta]] and [[IIT Kharagpur]] - Post Graduate Diploma in Business Analytics (PGDBA)<ref name=pgdba>{{cite web |url = http://www.isical.ac.in/~pgdba }}</ref> with an aim to nurture and develop highly skilled business analytical professionals.
Undergraduate courses are of 3 years duration, whereas the graduate level courses of 2 years of duration. For all undergraduate and graduate level courses, the academic year is divided in two semesters.<ref name=isiprospectus/> Except for sponsored candidates of MTech courses, ISI students are not required to pay any tuition fees.<ref name=isiprospectus/> Conditional to performance beyond a threshold, all students and research fellows receive stipends, fellowships and contingency/book grants.<ref name=isiprospectus/> Students demonstrating outstanding performances are rewarded at the end of the semesters.<ref name=isiprospectus/> ISI campuses provide hostel accommodations with recreational facilities and limited medical facilities available free of cost.<ref name=isiprospectus/>
=== Admissions === Applicants of all degree courses are required to go through written admission tests and interviews.<ref name=isiprospectus/> ISI conducts the written tests at various examination centres across India.<ref name=isiprospectus/> Only in few cases, candidates may get called for the interview directly, viz. applicants of MTech Computer Science course having a [[Graduate Aptitude Test in Engineering|GATE]] score above a threshold.<ref name=isiprospectus/> Also, candidates of research fellowship programmes having already qualified for a fellowship from [[Council of Scientific and Industrial Research|CSIR]] or [[National Board for Higher Mathematics|NBHM]], can directly appear in an interview.<ref name=isiprospectus/>
=== International Statistical Education Centre === In 1950, ISI, in collaboration with [[International Statistical Institute]], [[UNESCO]] and Government of India, had set up International Statistical Education Centre (ISEC) to impart knowledge of theoretical and applied statistics to participants from Middle East, East and South-East Asia, the Far East and Commonwealth countries of Africa.<ref name=sbrao/> The main training course offered by ISEC is meant for international students, preferably graduates with proficiency in English and Mathematics.<ref name=itec>{{cite web |url = http://itec.mea.gov.in/specialisedcourses.html#24 |title = List of ITEC/SCAAP Empanelled Institutes |publisher = [[Indian Technical and Economic Cooperation]] (ITEC) Programme, Technical Cooperation Division, [[Ministry of External Affairs (India)|Ministry of External Affairs]], Government of India |accessdate = 20 November 2012 }}</ref> ISEC, located in Kolkata campus of ISI, functions with support from the [[Ministry of External Affairs (India)|Ministry of External Affairs]] and the [[Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (India)|Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation]] of the Government of India.<ref name=isec>{{cite web |url = http://www.isical.ac.in/~isecweb/main.html |title = Preface |publisher = International Statistical Education |accessdate = 20 November 2012}}</ref>
=== Publications === ''[[Sankhya (journal)|Sankhya]]'', the statistical journal published by ISI, was founded in 1933, along the lines of [[Karl Pearson]]'s ''[[Biometrika]]''.<ref name=obit/> Mahalanobis was the founder editor.<ref name=sbrao>{{cite web |url = http://pib.nic.in/feature/fe0799/f0207991.html |title = Indian Statistical Institute – A Tradition |author = S. B. Rao |authorlink = S. B. Rao |publisher = [[Press Information Bureau]], Government of India |accessdate = 19 November 2012 }}</ref> Each volume of ''Sankhya'' consists of four issues; two of them are in Series A, containing articles on theoretical statistics, [[probability theory]] and [[stochastic process]]es, and the other two issues form the Series B, containing articles on applied statistics, i.e. applied probability, applied stochastic processes, [[econometrics]] and statistical computing.<ref name=sankhya>{{cite web | url = http://sankhya.isical.ac.in/index.html | title = Sankhya Home | accessdate = 23 November 2012}}</ref>
=== Rankings === According to India Education Review, no Indian university is in the world's top 200 universities.<ref name=ier>{{cite web |url = http://www.indiaeducationreview.com/news/no-indian-institute-worlds-top-200-qs-rankings-2012 |title = No Indian university in world's top 200: QS Rankings 2012 |publisher = India Education Review |date = 12 September 2012 |accessdate = 18 November 2012 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121010163030/http://www.indiaeducationreview.com/news/no-indian-institute-worlds-top-200-qs-rankings-2012 |archivedate = 10 October 2012 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> The ascribed ranking of ISI is 386.<ref name=4icu>{{cite web |url = http://www.topuniversities.com/institution/indian-statistical-institute |title = Indian Statistical Institute – Top Universities |year = 2011 |publisher = QS Top Universities |accessdate = 18 November 2012 }}</ref> The web ranking of this institute, according to 4ICU (4 International Colleges and Universities), is 1693.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.4icu.org/reviews/2040.htm |title = Indian Statistical Institute – Ranking & Review |publisher = 4International Colleges & Universities (4ICU) |year = 2012 |accessdate = 18 November 2012 }}</ref> According to the web ranking published by [[Webometrics Ranking of World Universities]], ISI currently holds the world rank of 1352.<ref name=webometrics>{{cite web |url = http://www.webometrics.info/en/Asia/India |title = India – Ranking Web Universities |publisher = [[Webometrics Ranking of World Universities|Webometrics]] |accessdate = 31 July 2018 }}</ref> In the subject-wise academic world ranking of Computer Science, Indian Statistical Institute features in 101—150 category.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/SubjectCS2015.html|title=Academic Ranking of World Universities in Computer Science - 2015 - 2015 Top 200 Universities in Computer Science - ARWU-SUBJECT 2015|website=www.shanghairanking.com}}</ref> The Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata is ranked 2nd in Computer Science research by mean citation rate, p-Index, h-index among all universities in India.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isical.ac.in/~pnc_ccsd/1320-5291-1-PB.pdf|title=Ranking of Indian Institutions Contributing to Computer Science Research, 1999-2008|publisher=}}</ref>
== Achievements == Over the years, researchers of ISI made fundamental contributions in various fields of Statistics such as [[Design of Experiments]], Sample Survey, [[Multivariate statistics]] and [[Computer Science]]. Mahalanobis introduced the measure [[Mahalanobis distance]] which is used in multivariate statistics and other related fields.<ref name=hist1023>{{harvnb|Ghosh|Maiti|Bera|2010|p=1023}}</ref> [[Raj Chandra Bose]], who is known for his contributions in [[coding theory]], worked on Design of Experiments during his tenure at ISI, and was one of the three mathematicians, who disproved [[Leonard Euler|Euler]]'s conjecture on [[Graeco-Latin square|orthogonal Latin squares]].<ref name=hist1020/> [[Anil Kumar Bhattacharya]] is credited with introduction of the measures [[Bhattacharyya distance]] and [[Bhattacharyya distance#Bhattacharyya coefficient|Bhattacharya coefficient]]. Samarendra Nath Roy is known for his pioneering contributions in multivariate statistics.<ref name=mardiasnroy>{{cite web | url = http://www1.maths.leeds.ac.uk/statistics/research/reports/2007/STAT07-07.pdf | format = PDF | title = On S.N. Roy's Legacy to Multivariate Analysis | author = Kanti V. Mardia | publisher = Department of Statistics, [[University of Leeds]] | date = 23 January 2008 | accessdate = 10 December 2012}}</ref> Among colleagues of Mahalanobis, other notable contributors were [[K. R. Nair]] in Design of experiments, [[J. M. Sengupta|Jitendra Mohan Sengupta]] in Sample Survey, Ajit Dasgupta in Demography and Ramkrishna Mukherjea in Quantitative Sociology.<ref name=hist1020/> C. R. Rao's contributions during his association with ISI include two theorems of [[Statistical Inference]] known as [[Cramér–Rao bound|Cramér–Rao inequality]] and [[Rao-Blackwell Theorem]], and introduction of [[orthogonal array]]s in Design of Experiments. [[Anil Kumar Gain]] is known for his contributions to the [[Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient]] with his colleague Sir [[Ronald Fisher]] at the [[University of Cambridge]].<ref name=hist1023/>
In 1953, India's first indigenous computer was designed by Samarendra Kumar Mitra who headed the Computing Machines and Electronics Laboratory at ISI Calcutta. The Indian Statistical Institute was also hosted the first two digital computers in South Asia; the HEC-2M from England in 1956, and the URAL from the Soviet Union in 1959. These were also among the earliest digital computers in Asia (outside Japan).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Menon|first=Nikhil|date=2018|title=‘Fancy Calculating Machine’: Computers and planning in independent India|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/modern-asian-studies/article/fancy-calculating-machine-computers-and-planning-in-independent-india/AE97E3E18914EDF1378E29CAE1579BB2|journal=Modern Asian Studies|volume=52|pages=421–457|via=JSTOR}}</ref>
During 1953 - 1956 distinguished scientists, like [[Ronald Fisher]], [[Norbert Wiener]] and [[Yuri Linnik]] visited ISI. [[Norbert Wiener]] collaborated with [[Gopinath Kallianpur]] on topics including [[ergodic theory]], [[prediction theory]] and generalized [[harmonic analysis]].<ref name="Norbert Wiener">{{cite web|title=Norbert Wiener and Probability Theory|url=http://www.ias.ac.in/resonance/Jan1999/pdf/Jan1999p32-34.pdf|publisher=[[Indian Academy of Sciences]]}}</ref> In 1962, during his month-long visit to ISI, Soviet mathematician [[Andrey Kolmogorov]] wrote his notable paper on [[Kolmogorov complexity]], which was published in Sankhya, 1963.<ref name=hist103132>{{harvnb|Ghosh|Maiti|Bera|2010|pp=1031–1032}}</ref> Other distinguished scientists including [[Jerzy Neyman]], [[Walter A. Shewhart]], [[W. Edwards Deming]] and [[Abraham Wald]] have visited ISI during the tenure of [[P. C. Mahalanobis]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Sarma|title=Statistics Made Simple Do It Yourself On Pc 2Nd Ed|publisher=PHI Learning Pvt. Ltd|page=3}}</ref>
=== Planning Commission === The [[Five-Year plans of India#Second Five-Year Plan .(1956.–.1961)|second five-year plan of India]] was a brainchild of Mahalanobis. The plan followed the [[Mahalanobis model]], an [[economic development]] model developed by Mahalanobis in 1953. The plan attempted to determine the optimal allocation of investment between productive sectors in order to maximise long-run economic growth . It used the prevalent state of art techniques of operations research and optimisation as well as the novel applications of statistical models developed at ISI. This second five-year plan shifted the focus from agriculture to industrialisation, with an objective of attaining self-reliance by economy of India. Domestic production of industrial products was encouraged in this plan, particularly in the development of the [[public sector]].<ref name=Das88>{{cite book |last = Das |first = Gurcharan |title = India Unbound From Independence to the Global Information Age |publisher = Penguin Books |page = 88 |isbn = 9780143063018 |year = 2002 }}</ref> The two-pronged strategy devised in this plan targeted rapid growth of the [[heavy industry]], keeping emphasis on growth of small and cottage industries.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.isical.ac.in/~isiaa/ISIAA%20Golden%20Jubilee%20Volume.pdf |title = The Indian Path of Development |date = 29 December 1981 |author = [[Indira Gandhi]] |publisher = Golden Jubilee Souvenir, ISI Alumni Association |accessdate = 16 November 2012 |pages = 9–10 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
[[Bagicha Singh Minhas|B. S. Minhas]] and [[Kirit Parikh|K. S. Parikh]], both from the Planning Unit of ISI Delhi, played key roles in the [[Planning Commission (India)|Planning Commission of the Government of India]]. Minhas, who joined the Planning Unit in 1962 and retired as a distinguished scientist in 1989, was a member of the Planning Commission during 1971–74.<ref name=planlist>{{cite web | url = http://planningcommission.nic.in/aboutus/history/past_memb.doc | title = List showing names of Members of Planning Commission | publisher = Planning Commission, Government of India | accessdate = 30 November 2012}}</ref><ref name=minhasobit>{{cite web | url = http://www.business-standard.com/india/news/b-s-minhas-down-to-earth-policy-analyst/223642/ | title = B S Minhas: Down-to-earth policy analyst | author = T. N. Srinivasan | authorlink = T. N. Srinivasan | publisher = [[Business Standard]], New Delhi | date = 15 September 2005 | accessdate = 30 November 2012}}</ref> Parikh, who was a member of the Planning Commission during 2004–09,<ref name=planlist/> chaired Integrated Energy Policy Committee of the commission,<ref name=direc2010>{{cite web | url = http://www.direc2010.gov.in/pdf/kirit-s-parikh.pdf | format = PDF | title = Dr. Kirit S. Parikh – DIREC (2010) | publisher = Delhi International Renewable Energy Conference (DIREC) 2010 | accessdate = 30 November 2012}}</ref> was a member of the [[Economic Advisory Council]] of India during the tenure of five prime ministers,<ref name=direc2010/> also played a role in the [[Department of Atomic Energy (India)|Department of Atomic Energy]] establishment, and was a key advisor to the government on energy issues.<ref name=direc2010/>
=== Computer science === In India, the first analog computer was designed by Samarendra Kumar Mitra and built by Ashish Kumar Maity at ISI in 1953, for use in computation of numerical solutions of simultaneous linear equations using a modified version of Gauss-Siedel iteration.<ref name=csi>{{cite web |url = http://www.csi-india.org/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=015efaaf-c6d4-4734-8b84-9240b906daa6&groupId=10616 |title = Glimpsing through Early Days of Computers in Kolkata |author = Devaprasanna Sinha |publisher = [[Computer Society of India]] |pages = 5–6 |date = August 2012 |accessdate = 17 November 2012 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In 1955, the first digital computer of India was procured by ISI.<ref name=csi/> This machine was of a model named HEC-2M, manufactured by [[British Tabulating Machine Company]] (BTM).<ref name=csi/> As per the agreement with BTM, ISI had to take care of the installation work and maintenance of it,<ref name=csi/> before it became operational in 1956.<ref name=dq>{{cite web |url = http://archive.dqindia.com/content/50yrsIT/DisruptingMoments/2006/106123005.asp |title = 50 Years of IT: Disrupting Moments: 1956–1965: The Beginning |publisher = [[Dataquest]] magazine, India |date = 30 December 2006 |accessdate = 18 November 2012 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130121151604/http://archive.dqindia.com/content/50yrsIT/DisruptingMoments/2006/106123005.asp |archivedate = 21 January 2013 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Though this HEC-2M machine and the URAL-1 machine, which was bought in 1959 from [[Russia]],<ref name=csi/> were operational till 1963,<ref name=csi/> ISI began development of the first second-generation digital computer of India in collaboration with [[Jadavpur University]] (JU).<ref name=csi/> This joint collaboration led by the head of the Computing Machines and Electronics Laboratory at ISI, Samarendra Kumar Mitra, produced the transistor-driven machine ISIJU-1, which became operational in 1964.<ref name=dq/> The first annual convention of the [[Computer Society of India]] (CSI) was hosted by ISI in 1965.<ref name=csi/><ref name=dq/> The Computer and Communication Sciences division of ISI produced many eminent scientists such as Samarendra Kumar Mitra (its original founder), [[Dwijesh Dutta Majumdar]], [[Sankar Kumar Pal]], [[Bidyut Baran Chaudhuri]], Nikhil R. Pal, Bhabani P. Sinha, Bhargab B. Bhattacharya, Malay K. Kundu, Sushmita Mitra, Bhabatosh Chanda, [[Chivukula Anjaneya Murthy|C. A. Murthy]], [[Sanghamitra Bandyopadhyay]] and many. ISI is regarded as one of the top most centres for research in computer science in India and attracts some of the best students in the country.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://eprints.rclis.org/bitstream/10760/7211/1/Das_Karanjai_ALIS_02.pdf |title = Institutional Distribution in Computer Science Research in India |author1 = Anup Kumar Das |author2 = Aruna Karanjai |accessdate = 2012-11-13 |publisher = Annals of Library and Information Studies 49,1 |year = 2002 |pages = 23–27 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The Knowledge-based Computer Systems project (KBCS), funded jointly by [[Department of Electronics and Information Technology]] (DoE), Government of India and [[UNDP]] since 1986, has a nodal centre at ISI Kolkata.<ref name=fas>{{cite web |url = http://www.fas.org/nuke/guide/india/agency/krithi2.html |title = Computer Science Research in India |author = Krithi Ramamritham |publisher = Federation of American Scientists (www.fas.org) |date = 8 November 1995 |accessdate = 16 November 2012 }}</ref> This unit is responsible for research in the area of image processing, pattern recognition, computer vision and artificial intelligence.<ref>{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/?id=QCYEJXzmbpQC&pg=PA248&lpg=PA248&dq=KBCS+UNDP+DOE+ISI#v=onepage&q=KBCS%20UNDP%20DOE%20ISI&f=false |title = Computer Education in India: Past, Present and Future |author = Utpal Kumar Bannerjee |publisher = Concept Publishing Company |page = 248 |date = 1 January 1996 |accessdate = 16 November 2012 |isbn = 9788170226093 }}</ref>
=== Social sciences === R. L. Brahmachari, known for his work in many fields like agricultural sciences, zoology, botany, biometrics, did much of his work at ISI.
The institute has done some pioneering work and research in anthropology and palaeontology. A trove of dinosaur fossils was discovered by a team led by ISI researchers in the early 1960s. The scattered fossils were recovered and the partial skeleton was reconstructed at ISI's Baranagar campus. It turned out to be a unique species and was named the ''[[Barapasaurus tagorei (Dinosauria: Sauropoda)]]'', after Rabindranath Tagore and was mounted in the Geology Museum at the Kolkata Campus of the Institute.
The Linguistic Research Unit (LRU) of ISI was involved in the study of speech pathology. [[Đorđe Kostić]] of this laboratory was a distinguished scientist. He invented a unique hearing aid, called SAFA (Selective Auditory Frequency Amplifier) that simulates frequency-range according to the need of the particular hearing impaired person.<ref name=kostic>{{cite web | url = http://www.serbian-corpus.edu.rs/ns/history/djk2/djko.htm | title = Đorđe Kostić | publisher = Institute for Experimental Phonetics and Speech Pathology, Belgrade | accessdate = 30 November 2012 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140928220142/http://www.serbian-corpus.edu.rs/ns/history/djk2/djko.htm | archivedate = 28 September 2014 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
=== Alumni ===
Many students and research scholars of ISI pursued a career in academics, and have excelled in the fields of statistics, mathematics, probability theory, computer science and economics. In statistics alumni of ISI who have been elected a [[List of Fellows of the American Statistical Association|Fellow of the American Statistical Association]] include [[P. V. Sukhatme]] (1950) and [[K. R. Nair]] (1951).
ISI alumni notable for non-academic career include politicians [[Subramanian Swamy]] and [[Dipankar Bhattacharya]].
== Visits by Heads of states == [[USSR|Soviet]] premier [[Nikita Khrushchev]] visited ISI during his visit to [[India]] in 1955.<ref name="Norbert Wiener" /> [[Zhou Enlai]], the [[Premier of the People's Republic of China|Prime Minister of China]], and [[Ho Chi Minh]], the [[President of Vietnam]], during their visit to [[India]] specifically visited ISI respectively on 9 September 1956 and 13 February 1958.<ref>{{cite web|last=Naithani|first=Pankaj|title=Remembering Prasanta Chandra Mahalanobis|url=http://www.mainstreamweekly.net/article1533.html|publisher=The Mainstream weekly|accessdate=25 July 2009}}</ref>
== Campuses == ISI has its headquarters and the main campus in Kolkata. It has other centres in New Delhi, Bangalore, Chennai and smaller units in Hyderabad, Mumbai, Coimbatore, Giridih, Pune and Vadodara.<ref name=campuslist>{{cite web|url = http://www.isical.ac.in/campus.php|publisher=Indian Statistical Institute|title=Campus|accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> Tezpur, the 4th centre of ISI was inaugurated in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.isine.ac.in/index.html |title = About our Institute |publisher = Northeast centre at Tezpur, Indian Statistical Institute |accessdate = 13 November 2012 }}</ref>
Since mid-forties, ISI pioneered in research and application of [[Statistical process control|Statistical Quality Control]] (SQC) in India.<ref name=evoln24>{{harvnb|Ghosh|Maiti|Rao|Sinha|1999|p=24}}</ref> [[Walter A. Shewhart]], the statistician known as ''the father of SQC'', and other experts of this field visited ISI over the years.<ref name=sbrao/> The first Statistical Quality Control and Operations Research (SQC & OR) unit of ISI was set up in Mumbai in 1953, followed by Bangalore and Kolkata units in 1954.<ref name=evoln24/> In 1976, this unit was transformed into the SQC & OR Division,<ref name=hist1032>{{harvnb|Ghosh|Maiti|Bera|2010|p=1032}}</ref> which now operates eight units, located at various industrial centres in India{{spaced ndash}}Kolkata, Delhi, Bangalore, Chennai, Pune, Mumbai, Coimbatore and Vadodara.<ref name=isidivs>{{cite web | url = http://www.isical.ac.in/departments.php | title = Division and Units | publisher = Indian Statistical Institute | accessdate = 26 November 2012}}</ref> These units partake in technical consultancy with public and private organisations, in addition with performing research and training activities.<ref name=sbrao/>
The branch at [[Giridih]] was set up in 1931 and it has two operational units, viz. the Sociological Research Unit and the Agricultural Research Unit.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.telegraphindia.com/1120630/jsp/jharkhand/story_15673895.jsp | title = ISI Giridih a sorry statistic – Research roadblock in cradle | author = Vishvendu Jaipuriar | publisher = [[The Telegraph (Calcutta)]] | date = 30 June 2012 | accessdate = 26 November 2012}}</ref>
=== Kolkata campus === [[File:Isical01.jpg|thumb|300 px|Main Building of Indian Statistical Institute, [[Kolkata]]]] ISI Kolkata has a campus consisting of six addresses at 201 through 206 [[Barrackpore Trunk Road]], [[Baranagar]]. These include a house, which was an erstwhile office of the [[National Sample Survey Organisation]] (NSSO) of India.
ISI Kolkata campus is eco-friendly, as conceived by Mahalanobis. Hollow bricks that protect from heat and noise were used with minimum use of reinforced concrete, to avoid radiation. There was no use of bitumen-basalt combination at the roads inside ISI campuses. This helps in reduction of radiation and preservation of rain water to maintain equilibrium in ground-water level.
The Kolkata campus offers bachelors level degree course in Statistics (B. Stat), master's degree course in Statistics (M.Stat), Mathematics (M.Math), Computer Science (MTech), Quality Reliability and Operations Research (MTech) and Quantitative Economics (M.S.).<ref name=prog/> Major divisions and units are: Statistics and Mathematics Unit (SMU), Human Genetics Unit (HGU), Physics and Applied Mathematics Unit (PAMU), Geological Studies Unit (GSU), Advanced Computation and MicroElectronics Unit (ACMU), Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition Unit (CVPRU), Machine Intelligence Unit (MIU), Electronics and Communication Sciences Unit (ECSU), Applied Statistics Unit (ASU), Economic Research Unit (ERU), Linguistic Research Unit (LRU), Sociology Research Unit (SRU), Psychometry Research Unit (PRU) and Population Studies Unit (PSU).
The Kolkata campus houses the International Statistical Education Centre (ISEC), which opened in 1950. This Centre provides training in statistics to sponsored students mainly from the Middle East, South and South East Asia, the Far East and the Commonwealth Countries of Africa. The Centre also offers various short-term courses in statistics and related subjects.
The Center for Soft Computing Research: A National Facility, an associate institute of Indian Statistical Institute and established in Kolkata in 2005, is unique in the country. Apart from conducting basic research, it offers a 3-month course and promotes less endowed institutes by providing fellowships and research grants.
The Central Library of ISI is located at Kolkata with branches at the other facilities. The library has over 200,000 volumes of books and journals with a special emphasis on the field of statistics and related studies. The main branch also has a collection of official reports, reprints, maps, and microfilms. The library receives over a thousand new technical and scientific journals every year. The Library has databases on CD-ROM and is working on further digitization of the collection. The library has a separate collection of works on the topics of mathematics and statistics called the Eastern Regional Centre of [[National Board for Higher Mathematics|NBHM]] collection, funded by grants from the [[National Board for Higher Mathematics]].
=== Delhi campus === <gallery> Image:Main road of ISI Delhi.JPG|Main road inside the Institute Image:Near main entrance of ISI Delhi.JPG|Gardens near the main entrance Image:Part of ISI Delhi campus near A9-A14.JPG|Night view of the campus Image:ISI Delhi canteen at night.JPG|Canteen Image:ISI Delhi Hostel.JPG|Hostel Image:ISI Delhi library building.JPG|Library </gallery> The ISI campus at New Delhi was established in 1974 and was shifted to the present campus in 1975.<ref name=isidhist>{{cite web |url = http://www.isid.ac.in |title = Indian Statistical Institute, Delhi Center |publisher = Indian Statistical Institute |accessdate = 18 November 2012 }}</ref>
The Delhi campus offers two master level courses Master of Statistics (M. Stat) and Master of Science (M. S.) in Quantitative Economics, and doctoral programs.<ref name=prog/>
=== Bangalore campus === <gallery> Image:ISI Bangalore main building 2.JPG|Main building Image:ISI Bangalore main hostel.JPG|Main hostel Image:ISI Bangalore Guest House.JPG|Guest House Image:ISI Bangalore auditorium.JPG|Auditorium </gallery> The Bangalore Centre of ISI started with a Statistical Quality Control and Operations Research (SQC&OR) unit in 1954.<ref name=evoln24/> The Documentation Research and Training Centre (DRTC) here became operational from 1962 with honorary professor [[S. R. Ranganathan]] as the head.<ref name=docencyclo>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/?id=HSFu99FCJwQC&pg=PA697&dq=indian+statistical+institute+ranganathan#v=onepage&q=indian%20statistical%20institute%20ranganathan&f=false | page = 697 | last = Wedeworth | first = Robert | publisher = American Library Association | year = 1993 | title = World Encyclopedia of Library and Information Services | edition = 3 | accessdate = 23 December 2012| isbn = 9780838906095 }}</ref> Prof. Mahalanobis planned of starting a full-fledged centre of ISI here around the mid-sixties. In 1966, the then [[Government of Karnataka]] granted ISI 30 acres of forest land full of [[eucalyptus]] trees, next to the upcoming campus of the [[Bangalore University]], located on the [[State Highway 17 (Karnataka)|Mysore Road]] on the outskirts of the city.<ref name=isibhome>{{cite web |url = http://www.isibang.ac.in |title = Home page, Indian Statistical Institute, Bangalore Centre |accessdate = 18 November 2012 }}</ref>
However, after death of Prof. Mahalanobis in 1972, the project of establishing Bangalore centre got temporarily shelved. The project was again revived during 1976–78. Concrete proposals were made to the Government of India to get grants for the development of the land already in possession of ISI, along with the construction of an academic block with a library and offices.<ref name=isibhome/>
In the meantime, a building was rented on [[Church Street (Bangalore)|Church Street]], in Bangalore downtown, and various activities of the Bangalore Centre started in September 1978. The Economic Analysis Unit (EAU) and the Statistics and Mathematics Unit (SMU) were established. The SQC&OR Unit and the DRTC unit, which were functioning from other rented buildings at that time, joined this new Centre.
As construction of the administrative block at the new campus got completed, the various units moved to the new campus in May 1985. The sprawling green wooded Campus has Residential Facility for students, faculty and staff.
The Bangalore centre was formally declared as a centre of ISI in September 1996.<ref name=isibhome/>
The Systems Science and Informatics Unit (SSIU) was established in 2009<ref name=isibhome/>
The Bangalore centre has by now became an institution well known for its academic activities in Mathematics, Statistics, Computer Science, SQC and Operations Research, Library and Information Science, and Quantitative Economics.<ref name=isibhome/>
The Bangalore campus offers bachelor level course Bachelor of Mathematics (B. Math), master level courses Master of Mathematics (M. Math), Master of Science (M. S.) in Library and Information Science and Master of Science (M. S.) in Quality Management Science, and doctoral programs.<ref name=prog/>
== Student life ==
=== Student Fest === {{main|Integration (festival)|l1=Integration}} Integration is the annual techno-cultural fest of Indian Statistical Institute, usually held during the first and second weekend of January each year. It is one of the biggest student fests in Kolkata, and attracts participation from all over the world.Also the performances of great artists are always a center of attraction for all.
=== Placement === Alumni of ISI{{spaced ndash}}including recipients of PhD degree{{spaced ndash}}are employed in government and semi–government departments, industrial establishments, research institutions, in India and other countries.<ref name=isiprospectus/> There is a placement cell in ISI Kolkata that organizes campus interviews by prospective employers in various campuses of ISI.<ref name=isiprospectus/> Since recent past, a high percentage of ISI alumni gets absorbed into jobs in [[analytics]], banking, finance and software industry.<ref name=htanalytics>{{cite web | url = http://www.hindustantimes.com/HTEducation/GreatCareers/The-number-crunchers/Article1-477250.aspx | title = The number crunchers | last = Bano | first = Rahat | publisher = [[The Hindustan Times]] | date = 17 November 2009 | accessdate = 15 December 2012 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140417044935/http://www.hindustantimes.com/hteducation/greatcareers/the-number-crunchers/article1-477250.aspx | archivedate = 17 April 2014 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
== Citations == {{Reflist|2}}
== References == {{Refbegin}} *{{cite journal |last1 = Ghosh |first1 = J. K. |authorlink1 = Jayanta Kumar Ghosh |last2 = Maiti |first2 = P. |last3 = Rao |first3 = T.J. |last4 = Sinha |first4 = B.K. |title = Evolution of Statistics in India |journal = International Statistical Review |date = April 1999 |volume = 67 |issue = 1 |pages = 13–34 |url = http://library.isical.ac.in/jspui/bitstream/10263/3935/1/Evolution%20of%20Statistics%20in%20India.pdf |ref = harv |doi = 10.1111/j.1751-5823.1999.tb00378.x |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130810073937/http://library.isical.ac.in/jspui/bitstream/10263/3935/1/Evolution%20of%20Statistics%20in%20India.pdf |archivedate = 10 August 2013 |df = dmy-all }} *{{cite book |editor1-last=Dasgupta |editor1-first=Uma |title=Science and Modern India: An Institutional History, C. 1784–1947 |publisher=Pearson Education India |year=2010 |isbn=978-8131728185 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=lrx3wLz4itkC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Uma+Dasgupta |chapter=Indian Statistical Institute: Numbers and Beyond, 1931–47 (chapter 33) |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=lrx3wLz4itkC&pg=PA1013&dq=Indian+Statistical+Institute+Numbers+and+Beyond&hl=en&sa=X&ei=A_qqULqpGYzSrQfXoIGYAg&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Indian%20Statistical%20Institute%20Numbers%20and%20Beyond&f=false |last1=Ghosh |first1=Jayanta |authorlink1=Jayanta Kumar Ghosh |last2=Maiti |first2=Pulakesh |last3=Bera |first3=Anil |authorlink3=Anil K. Bera |accessdate=9 December 2012 |ref=harv }} {{Refend}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} [[File:IndustrialSymbiosisWasteHeatExchange.png|250px|right|thumb|Example of Industrial symbiosis: [[waste heat|waste steam]] from a [[waste incinerator]] (right) is piped to an ethanol plant (left) where it is used as an input to their production process]]
'''Industrial Symbiosis'''<ref>Lombardi, D. R. and Laybourn, P. (2012), Redefining Industrial Symbiosis. Journal of Industrial Ecology, 16: 28–37. doi: 10.1111/j.1530-9290.2011.00444.x</ref> a subset of [[industrial ecology]]. It describes how a network of diverse organizations can foster eco-innovation and long-term culture change, create and share mutually profitable transactions - and improve business and technical processes.
Although geographic proximity is often associated with industrial symbiosis, it is neither necessary nor sufficient—nor is a singular focus on physical resource exchange. In practice, using industrial symbiosis as an approach to commercial operations – using, recovering and redirecting resources for reuse – results in resources remaining in productive use in the economy for longer. This in turn creates business opportunities, reduces demands on the earth’s [[natural resource|resources]], and provides a stepping-stone towards creating a [[circular economy]]. The industrial symbiosis model devised and managed by International Synergies Limited is a facilitated model operating at the national scale in the United Kingdom (NISP - National Industrial Symbiosis Programme), and at other scales around the world. International Synergies Limited has developed global expertise in IS, instigating programmes in Belgium, Brazil, Canada, China, Denmark, Finland, Hungary, Italy, Mexico, Poland, Romania, Slovakia, South Africa and Turkey, as well as the UK.<ref>AM Hein, M Jankovic, R Farel, B Yannou 2015. [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/281063831_A_Conceptual_Framework_for_Eco-Industrial_Parks A Conceptual Framework For Eco-Industrial Parks]. Proceedings of the ASME 2015 International Design Engineering Technical Conferences & Computers and Information in Engineering Conference IDETC/CIE 2015</ref> Industrial symbiosis is a subset of [[industrial ecology]], with a particular focus on material and energy exchange. Industrial ecology is a relatively new field that is based on a natural paradigm, claiming that an [[industrial ecology|industrial ecosystem]] may behave in a similar way to the natural [[ecosystem]] wherein everything gets recycled, albeit the simplicity and applicability of this paradigm has been questioned <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Levine|first1=S.H.|title=Comparing Products and Production in Ecological and Industrial Systems|journal=Journal of Industrial Ecology|date=2003|volume=7|issue=2}}</ref> <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jensen|first1=P. D.|title=Reinterpreting Industrial Ecology|journal=Journal of Industrial Ecology|date=2011|volume=15|issue=5|url=http://epubs.surrey.ac.uk/807042/1/PJensen_Reinterpreting_Industrial_Ecology.pdf}}</ref>.
==Introduction== [[Eco-industrial development]] is one of the ways in which [[industrial ecology]] contributes to the integration of economic growth and [[environmental protection]]. Some of the examples of eco-industrial development are:
* [[Circular economy]] (single material and/or energy exchange) * [[Greenfield land|Greenfield]] [[eco-industrial development]] (geographically confined space) * [[Brownfield land|Brownfield]] [[eco-industrial development]] (geographically confined space) * Eco-industrial network (no strict requirement of geographical proximity) * Virtual eco-industrial network (networks spread in large areas e.g. regional network) * Networked Eco-industrial System (macro level developments with links across regions)<ref>Agarwal A. & Strachan P. 2006. Literature review on eco-industrial development initiatives around the world and the methods employed to evaluate their performance / effectiveness, Consultancy Report prepared for Databuild Ltd. and National Industrial Symbiosis Programme, 7 May 2006, Available from {{cite web |url=http://www.abhishekagarwal.co.uk/7.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229213926/http://www.abhishekagarwal.co.uk/7.html |archivedate=29 December 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
"''This classification omits any industrial sector-wide approaches and appreciates the diversity of the industrial system which is a key feature of industrial symbiosis. It is aimed to include initiatives that focus on achieving utility sharing and symbiosis among diverse sectors of industry''".<ref>{{cite web|title=Literature review on eco-industrial development initiatives around the world and the methods employed to evaluate their performance / effectiveness |url=http://www2.rgu.ac.uk/abs/National%20Industrial%20Symbiosis/Report%20for%20Databuild%20New.pdf |publisher=The Robert Gordon University |accessdate=24 April 2014 |author=Mr. Abhishek Agarwal and Dr. Peter Strachan |date=2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130414040648/http://www2.rgu.ac.uk/abs/National%20Industrial%20Symbiosis/Report%20for%20Databuild%20New.pdf |archivedate=14 April 2013 }}</ref><ref>Agarwal A. & Strachan P. 2006. Literature review on eco-industrial development initiatives around the world and the methods employed to evaluate their performance / effectiveness, Consultancy Report prepared for Databuild Ltd. and National Industrial Symbiosis Programme, 7 May 2006, Available from {{cite web |url=http://www.abhishekagarwal.co.uk/7.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229213926/http://www.abhishekagarwal.co.uk/7.html |archivedate=29 December 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> It is the diversity and the openness of industrial symbiosis that makes it a unique approach to eco-industrial development.
Industrial symbiosis engages traditionally separate industries in a collective approach to [[competitive advantage]] involving physical exchange of materials, energy, water, and/or by-products. The keys to industrial symbiosis are [[collaboration]] and the [[synergistic]] possibilities offered by geographic proximity".<ref>Chertow, M. R. 2000. Industrial Symbiosis: Literature and Taxonomy, Annual Review of Energy and the Environment, 25: 313-337. </ref> Notably, this definition and the stated key aspects of industrial symbiosis, i.e., the role of collaboration and geographic proximity, in its variety of forms, has been explored and empirically tested in the UK through the research and published activities of the National Industrial Symbiosis Programme <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jensen|first1=P. D.|last2=et al.|title=Quantifying Geographic Proximity: Experiences from the United Kingdom's National Industrial Symbiosis Programme|journal=Resources, Conservation and Recycling|date=2011|volume=55|issue=7|url=http://epubs.surrey.ac.uk/29718/88/Quantifying_%27Geographic_Proximity%27_%28Jensen_et_al__2011%29.pdf}}</ref> <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lombardi|first1=D. R.|last2=Laybourn|first2=P.|title=Redefining Industrial Ecology|journal=Journal of Industrial Ecology|date=2012|volume=16|issue=1|url=http://www.casi2020.eu/app/web1/files/download/587_lombardi-laybourn-j-1530-9290-2011-00444-x.pdf}}</ref> <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jensen|first1=P. D.|title=The Role of Geospatial Industrial Diversity in the Facilitation of Regional Industrial Symbiosis|journal=Resources, Conservation and Recycling|date=2016|volume=107|url=http://epubs.surrey.ac.uk/845524/1/RoGID_Article_PDJensen.pdf}}</ref>.
Industrial symbiosis systems collectively optimize material and energy use at efficiencies beyond those achievable by any individual process alone. IS systems such as the web of materials and energy exchanges among companies in [[Kalundborg Eco-industrial Park|Kalundborg, Denmark]] have spontaneously evolved from a series of micro innovations over a long time scale;<ref>Ehrenfeld, J. and Gertler, N. 1997. Industrial Ecology in Practice: The Evolution of Interdependence at [[Kalundborg Eco-industrial Park|Kalundborg]], Journal of Industrial Ecology 1(1): 67.</ref> however, the engineered design and implementation of such systems from a macro planner’s perspective, on a relatively short time scale, proves challenging. Nevertheless, there are examples of industrial symbiosis being approached as national / regional initiatives with some significant success particularly in Europe.<ref>Costa I., Massard G. and Agarwal A. 2010. Waste management policies for industrial symbiosis development: case studies in European countries, Journal of Cleaner Production 18: 815-822.</ref>
Often, access to information on available by-products is difficult to obtain. These by-products are considered [[waste]] and typically not traded or listed on any type of exchange.
==Example== Recent work reviewed government policies necessary to construct a multi-gigaWatt [[photovoltaic]] factory and complementary policies to protect existing solar companies are outlined and the technical requirements for a '''symbiotic industrial system''' are explored to increase the manufacturing efficiency while improving the environmental impact of [[solar photovoltaic cells]]. The results of the analysis show that an eight-factory industrial symbiotic system can be viewed as a medium-term investment by any government, which will not only obtain direct financial return, but also an improved global environment.<ref>Pearce, J.M. 2008. "Industrial Symbiosis for Very Large Scale Photovoltaic Manufacturing", ''Renewable Energy'' 33, pp. 1101–1108. [https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.renene.2007.07.002]</ref> This is because synergies have been identified for co-locating glass manufacturing and photovoltaic manufacturing.<ref>A. H. Nosrat, J. Jeswiet, and J. M. Pearce, "[https://www.academia.edu/1505293/Cleaner_production_via_industrial_symbiosis_in_glass_and_largescale_solar_photovoltaic_manufacturing Cleaner Production via Industrial Symbiosis in Glass and Large-Scale Solar Photovoltaic Manufacturing]", ''Science and Technology for Humanity (TIC-STH), 2009 IEEE Toronto International Conference'', pp.967-970, 26-27 Sept. 2009. [https://dx.doi.org/10.1109/TIC-STH.2009.5444358 DOI]</ref> The [[waste heat]] from glass manufacturing can be used in industrial-sized [[greenhouse]]s for [[food production]].<ref>Rob Andrews and Joshua Pearce, "[https://www.academia.edu/1484967/Environmental_and_Economic_Assessment_of_a_Greenhouse_Waste_Heat_Exchange Environmental and Economic Assessment of a Greenhouse Waste Heat Exchange]", ''Journal of Cleaner Production'' '''19''', pp. 1446-1454 (2011). [https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2011.04.016 DOI].</ref> Even within the PV plant itself a secondary chemical recycling plant can reduce environmental impact while improving economic performance for the group of manufacturing facilities.<ref>M.A. Kreiger, D.R. Shonnard, J.M. Pearce, "[https://www.academia.edu/2310926/Life_Cycle_Analysis_of_Silane_Recycling_in_Amorphous_Silicon-Based_Solar_Photovoltaic_Manufacturing Life Cycle Analysis of Silane Recycling in Amorphous Silicon-Based Solar Photovoltaic Manufacturing]"''Resources, Conservation & Recycling'', 70, pp.44-49 (2013).[https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.resconrec.2012.10.002 DOI]</ref>
In DCM Shriram consolidated limited ([[Kota, Rajasthan|Kota]] unit) produces [[caustic soda]], [[calcium carbide]], [[cement]] and [[PVC]] resins.[[Chlorine]] and [[hydrogen]] are obtained as by-products from caustic soda production, while calcium carbide produced is partly sold and partly is treated with water to form [[slurry]](aqueous solution of [[calcium hydroxide]]) and [[ethylene]]. The chlorine and ethylene produced are utilised to form [[PVC]] compounds, while the slurry is consumed for [[cement]] production by [[Cement kiln#Wet process|wet process]]. [[Hydrochloric acid]] is prepared by direct synthesis where the pure chlorine gas can be combined with hydrogen to produce hydrogen chloride in the presence of UV light.<ref>DSCL Annual Report , 2011-12 "{{cite web |url=http://dcmshriram.com/images/downloads/overview/DSCL-AR-Lowres.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140801133904/http://dcmshriram.com/images/downloads/overview/DSCL-AR-Lowres.pdf |archivedate=1 August 2014 |df=dmy-all }}" ''Annual Report of DSCL, 2011-12'' ,pp.22-23.</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Sustainable development}} *[[Eco-industrial park]] *[[Industrial ecology]] *[[Industrial metabolism]]

One of the classic examples of the industrial symbiosis is the [[Kalundborg]] Industrial Symbiosis Network [http://www.symbiosis.dk/]. One of the nationally launched successful industrial symbiosis initiative is the UK [[National Industrial Symbiosis Programme]](NISP) [http://www.nisp.org.uk/] -->
